Award.AwardTitle: CGV: Medium: Collaborative Research: A Heterogeneous Inference Framework for 3D Modeling and Rendering of Sites

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Organizing and using 3D data related to physical sites is important in many applications such as historical reconstruction, architectural design, and urban planning. However, no method has been developed that exploits the full range of data types available for such sites. Useful data often comes from historical sources, and requires substantial processing to be useful. Some of this processing can be automated, but some of it must be done by humans. An as-yet unsolved problem is how to coordinate human effort to efficiently carry out this process. In the current project the PIs will address quantitative and qualitative accuracy issues in reconstructing 3D sites so as to allow for input and participation by different populations in building data sets, and will demonstrate a variety of applications using a heterogeneous 3D site representation. Specifically, the work will make the following contributions: new techniques for annotating heterogeneous input will be developed, balancing automated and human input; new techniques for coordinating digital computation, human computation, and machine learning will be devised; new tools for architectural analysis and design, and for material weathering analysis, will be developed based on the new 3D representation; and new ideas for storytelling from 3D data will be demonstrated. Project outcomes will include a new organization of heterogeneous data for 3D sites, new insights into the relative contributions of automated techniques and human computation in the domain of 3D site data (which will be applicable to other challenging problems involving large complex data sets), new algorithms for reconstructing 3D models, and new techniques for conducting studies in architecture and in cultural heritage.

Broader Impacts: This research will have a strong impact on architectural-design and cultural heritage documentation, interpretation and communication. The various phases of the project will involve students at both the graduate and undergraduate levels, and in diverse disciplines including computer science, architecture, and art history. The PIs will produce teaching modules based on this work targeted at computer science, architecture, and cultural heritage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop a system to organize a wide range of data types that when collected together provide a description of the history, use and current state of a site. Such a system is particularly important for cultural heritage sites where many records in the form of drawings, sketches, photographs, measurements and text may exist in different forms from different eras. The development of this system involved understanding how data is collected and analyzed, and how representations of sites are perceived by users.

The intellectual merit of the outcomes were a better understanding of the applicability of current methods, and insight into new interaction methods for organizing data and creating approximate 3D structures. In particular, several methods were examined for obtaining reconstructions of buildings and other site features from sketches and photographs. The project found that many methods that are successful using collections of modern photographs to automatically or semi-automatically reconstruct sites do not provide useful results for historic photograph collections. Instead, methods that reconstruct approximations of buildings by sketching on historic photographs, paintings, and drawings were developed. The reconstructions are formed as a series of strokes that begin on a plane and then are moved in 3D. While the sketches are approximate, and depend on the interpretation of the user, the source images and diagrams that are used to create them are embedded in the same sytem.  This is a unique new feature in a system for reconstrcution. The software system that was developed is called CHER-ish (for Cultural HERITAGE information on site history), and is freely available (both source and executable).

The broader impact of the outcome is that the CHER-ish system is now available for cultural heritage experts, and others, to use in collecting and analyzing data. This should permit scholars to obtain new insights, and help them communicate their insights. The project involved an interdisciplinary group including conservation scientists, computer scientist and an artist/designer. This group provided a rich introductory research experience for undergraduates involved in the project.
